descript.abstract: Political Territories is a polygon theme representing administrative territories worldwide, including countries, and in some cases, second level administrative units as well.
descript.purpose: For educational, non-commercial purposes. This dataset is appropriate for use in a GIS.
descript.supplinf:
The present-day political map of the world includes about 190 independent nations as well as territories of different status under jurisdiction of former metropolitan states of Europe, the United States of America, and some others. The basic political structure that we have today was mainly formed after World War II. In the decades from 1960 to the mid-1990s, the political changes generally took place first in Africa, Asia, and North America, and then in Australia and Oceania, and, most recently, in Europe and Asia.
In Europe, as a result of the disintegration of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Yugoslavia, and Czechoslovakia, more than a dozen and a half new nations appeared. One nation, the German Democratic Republic, disappeared from the political map.
The same process caused formation of five new countries in Asia (Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan) and one in Africa (Eritrea). Palestinian autonomy is forming on the Arab territories occupied by Israel. The newest country, Palau, was formed in Oceania from islands of the same name within the Caroline group that were a trust territory of the United States.
One hundred eighty-five countries are members of the United Nations organization. The Republic of Palau was admitted to the United Nations in December 1994.
The largest countries by area, those of more than 2 million square kilometers, are located in all the settled continents of the earth. The largest 13 countries are listed below with their locations and areas.

For support, you may contact Technical Support by telephone (voice) between 6:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. Pacific time, Monday through Friday, by dialing 888-377-4575; facsimile (fax) available at 909-792-0960; electronic mail (e-mail) support@esri.com; or visit http://support.esri.com; ESRI holidays excluded. Outside the United States Please direct all inquiries regarding software/data pricing, sales, support, and consulting services to your local ESRI International Distributor. This information can be found at http://gis.esri.com/intldist/contactint.cfm. For other questions or comments, you may contact ESRI headquarters by e-mail, telephone, or fax or write to us.

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.1850

procstep.procdesc:
The map of political structure was compiled from the ArcWorld 1:25 million-scale database. The international boundaries reflect de facto status as of January 1, 1996. The new countries that appeared in Europe, Asia, and Africa over recent years are shown. The FIPS (US Federal Information Processing Standard) coding scheme was the basis for the country codes, and the 1995 CIA World Fact Book (internet version) and the 1994-1995 Statesman's Year-Book were the sources for status and sovereignty. However, for the purposes of this atlas, Taiwan, Montenegro, and Serbia were classified as independent states, which diverges from the FIPS coding scheme.
First-order political subdivisions are shown for large countries (Russia, Canada, China, the United States, Brazil, Australia, India, Argentina, Mexico, Kazakhstan).
Datasets for each continent were converted from ESRI coverage to the ESRI shapefile format using the 'copy features' tool and merged into one layer using the 'merge' tool.
